qas.question: Slavic-speaking tribes were part of what prior to becoming known to the Roman world?
What were some of the multi-ethnic confederacies of Eurasia?

answers.text: the Sarmatian, Hun and Gothic empires

qas.question: Who started the great migration of the Slavs?
Some Slavs migrated with the movement of the Vandals to where?
Who were the Germanic tribes fleeing?
What empires were part of the Roman world?
When did the Sarmatians move westward?
Who settled in langs abandoned by the Slavs?

plausible_answers.text: Huns, and later Avars and Bulgars

qas.question: Who was fleeing from the Germans?
What theory suggests the Slavic tribes were unknown to the Roman world?

context: According to <b9_0>eastern homeland theory<b9_0/>, prior to becoming known to the Roman world, Slavic-speaking tribes were part of the many <a0_0>multi-ethnic confederacies of Eurasia<a0_0/> – such as <a1_0>the <b5_0>Sarmatian, Hun and Gothic<b5_0/> empires<a1_0/>. The Slavs emerged from obscurity when the westward movement of <a2_0>Germans<a2_0/> in <b6_0>the 5th and 6th centuries CE<b6_0/> (thought to be in conjunction with the movement of peoples from Siberia and Eastern Europe: <b8_0>Huns, and later Avars and Bulgars<b8_0/>) started the great migration of the Slavs, who settled the lands abandoned by <b7_0>Germanic tribes<b7_0/> fleeing <a4_0>the Huns and their allies<a4_0/>: westward into the country between the Oder and the Elbe-Saale line; southward into Bohemia, Moravia, much of present-day Austria, the Pannonian plain and the Balkans; and northward along the upper Dnieper river. Perhaps some Slavs migrated with the movement of the Vandals to <a3_0>Iberia and north Africa<a3_0/>.
